title: What is the difference of GarageBand and Logic Pro X? - Quora

response.answer_text: The main differences are in fine-grained control, and some pretty important basics missing from GB. Not knowing anything about you, I’ll just say that if you have a moderate amount of experience, and certainly if you’ve ever worked, even casually, at a studio console- you wouldn’t be happy with GarageBand. On the other hand, if you are a beginner, and/or doing very simple recordings, GB may be just what you need. The biggest things which kept me from playing with GB are the lack of aux sends/returns, no effects on the main outs, and the lack of detailed audio or MIDI editing (compared Logic or Cubase and the like). So (forgive me if I’m telling you things you already know), in GB you can’t have a “drum buss”. You can’t use a send for reverb on 3 (or whatever) background vocal tracks. You can’t do relative operations on MIDI data. Most of the plugins (instruments and processing) in GB are watered-down versions- like dynamics, which is pretty important to me. If you don’t know what any of that is, and just want to record yourself singing and playing guitar, then GB is fine. I can’t remember if you can edit an audio file at all, but if you can, it’s nothing like in Logic. One good thing about GB is that since it supports AU plugins, a $200 plugin will run in Logic or GB, and GB costs less, if money is a primary concern, but you still want, for example, a really nice compressor. Lastly, (I’m sure there’s lots others can add) with my audio interface, I can record 16 tracks at once (sounds like a lot, but if you record a band, you need at least 4 for the drums alone). I’m pretty sure GB only supports 8 simultaneously.

If you are serious about making music, whether as a hobby or a career, it’s time to pick up Logic Pro. Garageband is easy and fun but it’s incredibly limited in what it can do. One thing to keep in mind is that any serious recording software is going to have a bit of a learning curve. You may install the software, open it up, and have absolutely no clue where to start. That’s okay, any recording software (a.k.a. Digital Audio Workstation, a.k.a. DAW) is going to take some getting used to. There are a TON of resources on the internet that will teach you how to use Logic Pro X and many of them are free. I say go ahead and get Logic Pro!
